snippet: Stolen e-mails released by WikiLeaks set off a flurry of concern about a counterterrorist software program called TrapWire, but the fears appear to be wildly exaggerated.
abstract: New release of stolen corporate e-mails by WikiLeaks sets off a flurry of concern and speculation around the world about a counterterrorist software program called TrapWire, which analyzes images from surveillance cameras and other data to try to identify terrorists planning attacks; WikiLeaks Web site has been shut down by unidentified hackers in recent days, leading to speculation that it might be in retaliation for the e-mail leaks.
lead_paragraph: Stolen e-mails released by WikiLeaks set off a flurry of concern about a counterterrorist software program called TrapWire, but the fears appear to be wildly exaggerated.

headline.seo: TrapWire Antiterrorist Software Leaks Set Off Web Furor
headline.main: WikiLeaks Stirs Global Fears on Antiterrorist Software
headline.print_headline: WikiLeaks Stirs Global Fears on Antiterrorist Software
